content: 5 years on, gay marriage debate fades in Mass. While still opposed in some conservative circles, no prospect for referendum WHITINSVILLE, Mass., - Twenty years after he met the love of his life, nearly five years after their wedding helped make history, it took a nasty bout of pneumonia for Gary Chalmers to fully appreciate the blessings of marriage. "I was out of work for eight weeks, spent a week in the hospital," Chalmers said. "That was the first time I really felt thankful for the sense of the security we had, with Rich there, talking with the physicians, helping make decisions. ... It really made a difference." At stake was the most basic recognition of marital bonds — something most spouses take for granted. But until May 17, 2004, when Chalmers and Richard Linnell were among a surge of same-sex couples marrying in Massachusetts, it was legally unavailable to American gays and lesbians. Full article at ... >>>http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/30660002/

content: Massachusetts has proven that same-sex marriage does not destroy the sanctity of marriage or cause any of those slippery slope scenarios that the fear mongers have been spouting for years. Same-sex marriage became a non-issue in Massachusetts once the dust settled and the same thing will happen in all the States that allow us to get married. I will never understand why people want to make a Mountain out of a Mole Hill, you'd think we were trying to destroy the world instead of just getting a simple marriage certificate.

content: 5 years on, gay marriage debate fades in Mass. While still opposed in some conservative circles, no prospect for referendum WHITINSVILLE, Mass., - Twenty years after he met the love of his life, nearly five years after their wedding helped make history, it took a nasty bout of pneumonia for Gary Chalmers to fully appreciate the blessings of marriage. "I was out of work for eight weeks, spent a week in the hospital," Chalmers said. "That was the first time I really felt thankful for the sense of the security we had, with Rich there, talking with the physicians, helping make decisions. ... It really made a difference." At stake was the most basic recognition of marital bonds — something most spouses take for granted. But until May 17, 2004, when Chalmers and Richard Linnell were among a surge of same-sex couples marrying in Massachusetts, it was legally unavailable to American gays and lesbians. They should be PLEASED that a bunch of judges decided to redefine marriage to please a bunch of gays who wanted marriage instead of civil unions? It is a ******** attempt to gain social approval and support. These "gay rights" people have lost any legitimacy they had long ago. Massachusetts is a corrupt nightmare of a state when it comes to their government and this reflects that. I am ****ed that it has happened in my state of Connecticut, especially when we already offered civil unions! Hell, now they want to teach pro-gay nonsense in middle schools here. Given time there will be people demanding "marriage" for three or more people. These days I am all for the federal government officially defining marriage as what it really is. States can give out civil unions as they see fit. Yet when you don't want hear it you are automatically a homophobe or some other BS.
